questions.text: A young man who had fractured his left humerus previously now does not feel pain in his left little finger. On examination, the following deformity is observed. Which of the nerves is most likely to have been involved?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is cubitus valgus. This, along with the patient’s history of previous humerus fracture followed by loss of sensation over the little finger, points to the involvement of the ulnar nerve.

Cubitus valgus can occur as a late complication of nonunion of fracture of the lateral condyle of the humerus. The cubitus valgus deformity leads to the stretching of the ulnar nerve, resulting in classic neuropathic symptoms, which is termed tardy ulnar nerve palsy. Paresthesia in the ulnar nerve distribution with atrophy of the intrinsic hand muscles can be seen. It can be treated with ulnar nerve transposition and cubitus valgus correction.

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals in the hand. The lumbricals have a combined action on metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint flexion and interphalangeal (IP) joint extension (glass holding posture). In ulnar nerve injury, since the medial lumbricals are not functional, the forearm muscles are unopposed. Hence, there is hyperextension at MCP joints and flexion at IP joints. This causes claw hand deformity. There is also numbness in the medial one-and-a-half fingers.

questions.text: Sequentially arrange the structures of the renal hilum from anterior to posterior.

choices.text: Renal artery, renal vein, renal pelvis
Renal vein, renal artery, renal pelvis
Renal pelvis, renal artery, renal vein
Renal vein, renal pelvis, renal artery

questions.solution:
Hilum of the kidney contains the following structures from anterior to posterior:

  • Renal vein
  • Renal artery
  • Renal pelvis

questions.text: What is the Couinaud liver segment pointed to in the image?
questions.solution:
The Couinaud segment pointed in the cadaveric specimen is IV (4).

The segment IV lies between the umbilical fissure and the main portal fissure. The quadrate lobe is within this segment.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Couinaud's Segments

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

questions.text: Which of the following zones gives rise to benign prostatic hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
The zone marked C  is the transitional zone and it gives rise to benign prostatic hyperplasia. It is identified by its location, as it encircles the urethra. Therefore, it is also called the periurethral zone.

Zones of prostate and their clinical importance:

Zone Clinical importance
Transitional zone Benign prostatic hyperplasia
Peripheral zone Prostate cancer
Central zone Rarely involved in a disease

questions.text: You are assisting a surgeon performing a hepatic surgery and during the procedure, you suddenly encounter a significant amount of bleeding. To control the blood loss,  where should the clamp be applied?
questions.solution:
The clamp will be applied at the porta hepatis to minimize the blood loss.

Pringle maneuver: Rapid control of the vessels entering the porta hepatis can be obtained by compressing them in the free edge of the lesser omentum.

Porta hepatis is a deep, transverse fissure that is situated on the inferior surface of the right lobe of the liver.

Structures entering at porta hepatis:

  • Portal vein
  • Hepatic artery
  • Hepatic nervous plexus

Structures exiting the porta hepatis:

  • Right and left hepatic bile ducts
  • Lymphatics

questions.text: An autopsy is being conducted on a person who was diagnosed with normal pressure hydrocephalus. An axial dissection of the brain reveals one of the ventricles that is enlarged in this disease. Enlargement of the anterior horn of this ventricle causes compression of which of the following structures laterally?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an axial section of the lateral ventricle seen from posterior to anterior. The lateral relation of the anterior horn is the caudate nucleus. Enlargement of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle causes compression of the caudate nucleus laterally.

The clinical symptoms of normal-pressure hydrocephalus are characteristic of the classic triad of cognitive dysfunction, urinary symptoms, and a wide-based gait (wet, wacky, and wobbly). Additionally, depressed affect and UMN signs in lower limbs may be seen.
The diagnosis is established by a CT that shows a marked enlargement of ventricles and the Miller Fisher test that shows improvement in gait following a lumbar tap. Treatment generally involves ventriculoperitoneal shunting.

The lateral ventricle can be divided into the body and 3 horns—anterior, posterior, and inferior.

The locations of the parts: 

  • Body: Frontal and parietal lobe
  • Anterior horn: Frontal lobe
  • Posterior horn: Occipital lobe
  • Inferior horn: Temporal lobe

Anterior horn:

Extent: from the genu of the corpus callosum till the interventricular foramen

Relations: 

  • Anteriorly: Genu and rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Roof: Anterior part of the body of the corpus callosum 
  • Floor and lateral wall: Caudate nucleus
  • Medial wall: Septum pellucidum and anterior column of fornix

Body or Central part:

Extent: from the interventricular foramen till the splenium of the corpus callosum

Relations:

  • Roof: Body of the corpus callosum
  • Medial wall: Septum pellucidum 
  • Floor (from lateral to medial): Caudate nucleus, stria terminalis, thalamostriate vein, thalamus, choroid plexus, and body of the fornix

Posterior horn: 

Extent: from the splenium till the occipital pole

Relations:

  • Roof and lateral wall: tapetum of corpus callosum
  • Medial wall: Forceps major and calcar avis (calcarine sulcus)

Inferior horn: the largest compartment

Extent: till 2.5 cm from the temporal pole

Relations:

  • Roof: tapetum of corpus callosum and tail of caudate nucleus
  • Floor (lateral to medial): Collateral eminence (produced by collateral fissure, hippocampus)

Note: There is no lateral wall for the lateral ventricle.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl playing with small magnets suddenly develops breathlessness. Chest X-ray shows an inhaled foreign body in one of the bronchi. Where does the vein supplying the most likely site of obstruction drain into?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario of an inhaled foreign body, it is most likely to lodge into the right bronchus. The right bronchial veins drain to the azygos vein. 

Left bronchial veins drain into the accessory hemiazygos vein or left superior intercostal vein.

Clinical significance:

The right principal bronchus is wider, shorter, and more vertical. This is why an inhaled foreign body is more likely to lodge there. Also, the tracheal bifurcation directs the foreign body to the right lung

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in red color, in the image below:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is sigmoid sulcus.

  • The sigmoid sulcus is a wide groove, present anteriorly, in the mastoid part of the temporal bone.
  • It contains the sigmoid sinus.
  • Superiorly the sigmoid sulcus is continuous with the transverse sulcus.
  • Inferiorly, it crosses the occipitomastoid suture and grooves the jugular process of the occipital bone.

Other options:

Option a:  Pre-chiasmatic sulcus (also called chiasmatic groove or optic groove) is a transverse groove in the sphenoid bone, between the optic canals. The optic chiasma lies over the pre-chiasmatic sulcus.

Option c: Carotid sulcus is a shallow groove in the lateral wall of the body of the sphenoid. It contains the internal carotid artery.

Option d: Transverse sulcus is the groove for transverse sinus in the occipital bone, as shown below.

questions.text: An anatomy student while studying the structures forming the roof of the mouth notices the regions 'A" and 'B" as shown in the below image. Which of the following vessels supply the region marked as "A"?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as "A" in the above image is Hard Palate, which is mainly supplied by the greater palatine artery.

The palate forms the roof of the mouth and is divisible into two regions namely, Hard palate in front and soft palate behind

The boundary between the hard and soft palate is readily palpable and may be distinguished by a change in colour, the soft palate being a darker red with a yellowish tint.

Blood supply of the palate:

  • The hard palate is mainly supplied by the greater palatine artery which is a branch of the third part of the maxillary artery.
  • The soft palate is supplied by the ascending palatine branch of the facial artery, ascending pharyngeal artery, and lesser palatine arteries.

questions.text: The excitation of a particular cranial nerve leads to a decrease in the heart rate. Through which foramen does this nerve cross the base of the skull?
questions.solution:
Excitation of the vagus nerve leads to a decrease in the heart rate. The vagus nerve passes through the jugular foramen which is marked as 4 in the above image. 

Structures passing through the jugular foramen are the Inferior Petrosal sinus that continues as IJV, Cranial nerves IX, X & XI.

Other foramina marked in the above image:

  • 1 - Foramen rotundum
  • 2 - Foramen ovale
  • 3 - Foramen spinosum

questions.text: Identify the area marked with a red arrow.
questions.solution:
The area marked in the red arrow is the hypoglossal trigone.

The above image represents the floor of the fourth ventricle. It is a shallow diamond-shaped depression on the dorsal surfaces of the pons and the rostral half of the medulla. It contains the nuclei of the cranial nerves (V-XII).

Structures on the floor of the 4th ventricle (Rhomboid Fossa)

Ridges:

  • Transverse fibers: Striae medullaris
  • Striae medullaris divides the rhomboid fossa into 2parts: Rostral pontine and Caudal medullary

Medial to lateral in rostral pontine part:

  • Midline longitudinal sulcus: Median sulcus
  • Bilateral eminences: Medial eminence
  • Bilateral longitudinal sulcus: Sulcus limitans
  • Bilateral areas: Vestibular area (deeper to it is the vestibular nucleus)

Upper and lower ends of sulcus:

  • The bluish-colored, uppermost area where sulcus limitans ends: Locus coeruleus
  • Depression, the upper area of sulcus limitans: Superior fovea
  • Depression, the lower area of sulcus limitans: Inferior fovea

Cranial nerve nucleus elevations:

  • Elevation on the medial eminence: Facial colliculus
  • Elevations in the lowermost area in the shape of 2 triangles: Hypoglossal and vagal triangles

Circumventricular organ:

  • Between the vagal triangle and gracile tubercle below: Area postrema

questions.text: The structure that is related to the area marked 'A' in the given image is derived from:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the left lung and structure related to the marked area 'A' is the arch of the aorta which is derived from the left fourth aortic arch.

In the given image, the left lung is identified by the presence of the vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum - pulmonary artery, principal (hyparterial) bronchus, and inferior pulmonary vein. The image also shows an oblique fissure dividing the lung into superior and inferior lobes.

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures. They give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.

The 4th aortic arch persists on both sides and forms different structures on either side:

  • Left side - part of the arch of the aorta between the left common carotid and the left subclavian arteries
  • Right side - proximal segment of the right subclavian artery

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Various Aortic Arches

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures which give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.

questions.text: A patient who is being evaluated for an abnormal gait was asked to stand on one leg. It was observed that his opposite side pelvis began to drop. Identify the point of insertion of the affected muscles in the image below.
questions.solution:
The scenario describes the Trendelenburg sign. The muscles affected are the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus. They are attached to the greater trochanter which is labeled as 1 in the image.

Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb.

Causes of positive Trendelenburg sign:

  • Paralysis of the abductor muscles: Gluteus medius and gluteus minimus (injury, polio)
  • Damage to the superior gluteal nerve
  • Dislocation of the hip
  • Destruction of the head of the femur
  • Fracture neck of the femur
  Gluteus medius Gluteus minimus
Origin External surface of ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines External surface of ilium between inferior and anterior gluteal lines
Insertion Lateral surface of greater trochanter Anterolateral aspect of greater trochanter
Innervation Superior gluteal nerve (L4,L5,S1) Superior gluteal nerve (L4,L5,S1)
Arterial supply Superior gluteal artery Superior gluteal artery
Action Abduction & medial rotation of thigh.
Maintains the trunk upright when the foot of the opposite side is raised from the ground while walking		 Abduction & medial rotation of thigh.
Maintains the trunk upright when the foot of the opposite side is raised from the ground while walking

The image below shows attachments of various muscles over the posterior surface of the right femur.

Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: A surgeon is performing transurethral resection for a patient with an enlarged prostate gland. The prostatic part of the urethra where he operates contains which of the following types of epithelium?
questions.solution:
The prostatic urethra is lined by both urothelium and pseudostratified/stratified columnar epithelium.

The proximal part of the prostatic urethra (i.e. up to the opening of the ejaculatory duct) is lined by the transitional epithelium (urothelium). Whereas the distal part of the prostatic urethra is lined by the stratified or pseudostratified columnar epithelium.

questions.text: An anatomy resident while observing the histological section of the thymus under high magnification identifies the following structure in the medullary area of the thymus. These structures are derived from which pharyngeal pouch?
questions.solution:
The magnified view of the histology slide shows the Hassall’s corpuscles (thymic corpuscles) which are seen in the medullary area of the thymus. They are derived from the 3rd pharyngeal pouch.

Hassall’s corpuscles are small rounded structures formed from whorls of medullary epithelial cells with a central partially keratinized core appearing as eosinophilic staining mass.

The 3rd pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the thymus in the ventral part and the inferior parathyroid gland in the dorsal part. The thymus then moves away from the pharyngeal wall in a caudal and medial direction, pulling the inferior parathyroid with it. It reaches the anterior part of the thorax, where it fuses with its counterpart from the opposite side.

The endodermal cells of the thymus get invaded by the vascular mesoderm, which contains numerous lymphoblasts. Hassall’s corpuscles (thymic corpuscles) are derived from the endoderm of the 3rd pouch.

The following image describes the derivatives of the pharyngeal pouches.

 

Other options:

Option A - First pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the middle ear cavity and eustachian tube.

Option B - Second pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the palatine tonsils and tonsillar fossa.

Option D - Fourth pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the superior parathyroid gland, ultimobranchial body which then develop into the parafollicular "C" cells of the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A patient presents with a loss of taste sensation on the marked 'A' region of the tongue. Which of the following nerves is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The area marked as A in the above image is in the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. The nerve likely to be affected is the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Nerves mediating the taste sensation in different parts of the tongue: 

  • Chorda tympani branch of facial nerve - anterior 2/3rd of the tongue 
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve -
    • Posterior 1/3rd of the tongue
    • Circumvallate papillae
    • Post-sulcal part of the tongue
    • Palatoglossal arches
    • Oropharynx
  • Internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve - posterior most (vallecullae, epiglottis) tongue.

The glossopharyngeal nerve is the IX cranial nerve. It leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath. Its branches are tympanic, carotid, pharyngeal, muscular, tonsillar, and lingual branches.

Nerve supply by glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Sensory fibers to the uvula, tympanic cavity, pharyngotympanic tube, tonsils, fauces, nasopharynx, and posterior 1/3rd of the tongue
  • Motor fibers to the stylopharyngeus muscle
  • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland
  • Gustatory fibers for the postsulcal part of the tongue

Pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and vagus nerve form the pharyngeal plexus of nerves. These plexes mainly supply the pharynx. It also has contributions from the superior cervical ganglion. 

Glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve examinations include:

  • Observe the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula at rest and with phonation (“aah”).
  • By assessing the strength of the cough.

Infection, malignancy, and postoperative inflammation of the tonsil and tonsillar fossa will cause referred pain in the ear. This is conducted through the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve.

questions.text: A 69-year-old male presented with diplopia. Investigations revealed an aneurysm of the right anterior inferior cerebellar artery that is directly impinging on the nerve arising at the pontomedullary junction. Which of the following extraocular muscles is likely to be paralyzed?
questions.solution:
The lateral rectus muscle is likely to be paralyzed as it is innervated by the VI cranial nerve, which emerges from the pontomedullary junction (PMJ). 

Cranial nerves VI, VII, and VIII arise at the PMJ.

Extraocular muscles are innervated by the III, IV, and VI cranial nerves. The superior oblique is innervated by CN IV, the lateral rectus by CN VI, and all the other muscles by CN III. 

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: Which of the following structure marked in the given image is involved in Millard Gubler syndrome?
questions.solution:
The structure no.3 that is marked in the given image is the abducens nerve (6th nerve). It is involved in Millard Gubler syndrome which results from basilar artery stroke. Millard Gubler syndrome is a pontine lesion affecting 6th, 7thcranial nerve, and fibers of corticospinal tract.

Features are:

  • 6th nerve: Diplopia, ipsilateral convergent squint 
  • 7th nerve:  Loss of corneal reflex, ipsilateral paralysis of facial muscles
  • Corticospinal tract: Contralateral hemiplegia of extremities (due to involvement of pyramidal tract).

questions.text: Which of the following is not the content of the triangle marked as E in the given image?
questions.solution:
The triangle marked as "E" in the above image represents muscular triangle and mylohyoid muscle is not the content of muscular triangle.

Boundaries of muscular triangle:

  • Anteriorly by the median line of the neck from the hyoid bone to the sternum
  • Inferoposteriorly by the anterior margin of sternocleidomastoid
  • Posterosuperiorly by the superior belly of omohyoid

The triangle contains omohyoid, sternohyoid,sternothyroid, and thyrohyoid muscles.

Other triangles marked in the above image:

  • A – Carotid triangle
  • B – Occipital triangle 
  • C – Subclavian triangle
  • D – Digastric triangle

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: A 19-year-old football player was brought to the hospital after he suffered an ​injury caused by a lateral blow to the knee joint. MRI revealed the injury to the ligaments commonly referred to as the unhappy triad. Which of the following ligament is not involved in the unhappy triad?
questions.solution:
The ligaments involved in the unhappy triad of knee joint are medial meniscus, anterior cruciate ligament, and tibial collateral ligament. It is also known as O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triangle.

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

The image below shows the unhappy triad of the knee joint on MRI (PDW SPIR):

  1. Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Rupture of the medial collateral ligament
  3. Inner meniscal tear (image shows complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text:
Which of the following arteries are branches of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery?
  1. Superior gluteal artery
  2. Superior vesical artery
  3. Inferior vesical artery
  4. Inferior gluteal artery
  5. Iliolumbar artery
questions.solution:
The superior gluteal artery and iliolumbar artery are branches of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

Branches of the posterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  • Superior gluteal artery
  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  • Obturator artery
  • Superior vesical artery
  • Inferior vesical artery 
  • Inferior gluteal artery
  • Middle rectal artery
  • Vaginal artery (in females)
  • Uterine artery (in females)
  • Internal pudendal artery

questions.text: A college-going student was brought to the hospital with pain and swelling of the right hand and inability to move the fingers. The symptoms had developed after he had punched a wall during a fight. X-ray reveals a fracture as shown by the arrow. The long bone fractured in the X-Ray is of which of the following types?
questions.solution:
Given X-Ray shows the fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal bone. Metacarpals are miniature long bones.

Long bones are classified as follows:

  • Typical long bones (see figure) have an elongated shaft (diaphysis) and two expanded ends (epiphysis). The shaft has a central medullary cavity and a nutrient foramen directed away from the growing end. E.g., humerus, ulna, radius, femur, tibia, and fibula.
  • Miniature long bones contain only one epiphysis. E.g., metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges.
  • Modified long bones have a modified shaft or end, and no medullary cavity. E.g., clavicle.

Note: Extra-articular fracture of the fifth metacarpal neck is seen in Boxer's fracture. It is caused by striking an hard object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing, or occasionally by a direct injury.

questions.text: An intern in ICU decides to insert a central venous catheter through a femoral vein in a burns victim to administer IV fluids. However, while inserting the needle, he accidentally injured a solid structure lying immediately medial to the femoral vein, lying within the femoral sheath. Which of the following drains into the injured structure?
questions.solution:
Deep inguinal lymph node (also known as the node of Cloquet) lies medial to the femoral vein and is likely to be injured in this case. The glans penis drains into the deep inguinal lymph node whereas, the rest of the penis drains into the superficial lymph nodes.

The scrotum drains into superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

Femoral sheath is divided into three compartments:

  • The lateral compartment contains the femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains the femoral vein
  • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains lymphatic vessels, areolar tissue, and lymph node of Cloquet.

Related Pearl: Lymphatic drainage of pelvic structures

LYMPH NODES STRUCTURES DRAINING
Para - aortic lymph nodes Ovaries /Testis
External iliac lymph nodes Uterine body, cervix, superior bladder
Internal iliac lymph nodes Prostate, cervix, corpus cavernosum,proximal vagina
Superficial inguinal lymph nodes Distal vagina, vulva, scrotum, distal anal canal
Deep inguinal lymph nodes Glans penis

 

*Ref - Snells Clinical Anatomy - 4e

Ventral rami of T1 nerve, intercostal vein and superior intercostal artery

questions.solution:
The anterior relations of the neck of the first rib from medial to lateral are as follows: SVAN

  • Vein (posterior intercostal)

  • Nerve (T1 nerve)

questions.text: In the given image, the perineal membrane is denoted by:
questions.solution:
In the given image of a median sagittal section of a male perineum, the perineal membrane is denoted by the arrow marked as C.

The perineal membrane divides the urogenital triangle into:

  • A deep perineal space lying above it
  • A superficial perineal space lying below it

It has a distinct dorsal and a ventral portion, which are closely connected with Levator ani.
The dorsal portion is related to the support of the perineal body and lateral vaginal wall by its attachment to the ischiopubic ramus. The ventral portion, on the other hand, is contiguous with the structures supporting urethra.

The marked membranes in the given image are as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not related to the posterior surface of the vagina?
questions.solution:
Waldeyer's fascia (presacral fascia) forms the posterior relationship of the rectum and is not related to the vagina. It lines the anterior surface of the sacrum.

Relations of the vagina:

Parts of vagina Anterior relation Posterior relation Lateral relation

Levator ani

questions.text: Histological image of the cerebellum is given below. What is false about the cells marked in the given image?

choices.text: These cells are arranged in a layer between the molecular and granular layers
They are the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex
These cells are inhibitory in nature

questions.solution:
The cells marked in the above histological image are Purkinje cells and they use γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) as their neurotransmitter.

Characteristics of Purkinje cells:

  • Purkinje cells are the flask-shaped cells present in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum.
  • The cells are evenly spaced and are arranged in a single layer.
  • A dendrite arises from the neck of each flask-shaped cell, which passes upward to enter the molecular layer, which then branches extensively to form a dendritic tree.
  • The axon of each cell passes downwards, crosses the granular cell layer to enter the white matter.
  • Axons of Purkinje cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex.
  • The initial segment of the axon receives synaptic contacts from basket cell axons.
  • The main axon terminates in one of the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei.
  • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter.

Pathological significance:

  • Negri bodies in rabies, are usually found as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells.
  • Loss of Purkinje cells and granule cells is seen in ataxia-telangiectasia.
  • In patients with subacute cerebellar degeneration, there is the destruction of Purkinje cells. Some patients show circulating the PCA­1 antibody (anti­Yo) against Purkinje cells.
  • Purkinje cells and neurons in pyramidal cell layers of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex are the most sensitive neurons to hypoxia and are likely to be damaged in cases of global cerebral ischemia.

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Which layer of the epidermis do keratinocytes originate from?
questions.solution:
Keratinocytes are derived from stem cells present in the stratum basale, which is marked as layer "4" in the given image.

The epidermis consists of two types of cells: keratinocytes (predominant) and non-keratinocytes (melanocytes, dendritic cells of Langerhans, Merkel cells).

The image shows the histological appearance of the epidermis of the skin. The structures marked are as follows:

  • 1 - Stratum corneum
  • 2 - Stratum granulosum
  • 3 - Stratum spinosum
  • 4 - Stratum basale

The above 4 layers are present in the thin hairy skin. 

The thick glabrous skin over the palms and the soles alone contains a clear homogenous 5th layer between the stratum corneum and stratum granulosum, called the stratum lucidum. 

The epidermis of the skin is made of stratified squamous keratinized epithelium and consists of the following layers. 

  • Stratum basale - It is the deepest layer of the epidermis and is made of a single layer of columnar cells that rest on a basal lamina. It contains stem cells that undergo mitosis to give rise to keratinocytes and is also called stratum germinativum. 
  • Stratum spinosum - Contains several layers of polygonal keratinocytes. These cells are connected to each other with the help of desmosomes. This is also called as prickle cell layer or Malpighian layer.
  • Stratum granulosum - These are made up of flattened cells that have deeply staining granules in their cytoplasm. They are characterized by the presence of deeply staining keratohyalin granules in the cytoplasm. The cells of this layer have Golgi-derived lamellar granules that undergo exocytosis and form a lipid-rich impermeable layer around the cells. This material plays a major role in the skin barrier against water loss.
  • Stratum lucidum - It lies superficial to the stratum granulosum. The cell boundaries are indistinct and this layer appears homogenous.
  • Stratum corneum - It is the most superficial layer of the epidermis. This layer is acellular. It is made up of flattened scale-like elements (squames) containing keratin filaments within a protein. The squames are held together by a glue-like material that contains lipids and carbohydrates. This layer is highly resistant to permeation by water due to its high water content.

The following image shows the layers of the epidermis.

Related Pearl: Cells of the epidermis

Cells of the epidermis Origin and location Characteristic features
Keratino-cytes

Present in- All Layers of Epidermis (90-95% of all epidermal cells)

Derived from-Ectoderm

Differentiated in situ

 Rich in the intermediate filaments called keratin that provides mechanical strength to the cell. The keratinocytes in basal layer divide and generate the upper layers. 
Melano-cytes

Present in- Stratum basale

Derived from-Neural Crest

Migrate to the epidermis

 Synthesize melanin in granules called melanosomes that is transferred to keratinocytes of epidermis through elongated processes called dendrites. Each melanocyte transfers melanosomes to 36 keratinocytes. This is called as Epidermal melanin unit (36K:1M)   

Merkel   cells

Present in-Stratum basale (RETE RIDGES)

Derived from-Ectoderm/ Neural Crest

Differentiates in-situ

 Also known as Touch cells or Haascheiban cells. They are Type 1 slow adapting touch receptors.  
Langerhans cells

Present in-Stratum spinosum

Derived from- Bone Marrow

Migrate to Epidermis

 They are dendritic Antigen Presenting Cells (APCs).   Characterized by presence of rod shaped or Tennis Racket shaped granules called Birbeck granules which are seen on electron microscopy.   Immunohistochemical Markers are CD1a, CD207(Langerin) and S100.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient is posted for an inguinal hernia operation. The anesthetist intends to use a regional anesthesia technique that blocks the nerves in the anterior abdominal wall. Between which of the following structures would the anesthetist be injecting the drug mixture?

choices.text: Between internal oblique and external oblique
Between internal oblique and rectus abdominis
Between internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.solution:
The local anesthetic is injected between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles in the anterior abdominal wall. This is because the neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies between these two muscles.

The transversus abdominis plane (TAP) block is a regional anesthetic technique for abdominal surgery. 

The neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis in the anterior abdominal wall.

The plane contains:

  • Lower 6 thoracic nerves (T7-12)
  • Iliohypogastric nerves
  • Posterior intercostal and subcostal vessels
  • Anastomosis between superior and inferior epigastric arteries

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient had undergone prolonged surgery in a  prone position with his hip extended. Post-operatively he complained of pain, numbness, and paresthesia along the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. What is the root value of the nerve involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of prolonged surgery in prone position with hip extended and symptoms of paresthesia over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh is suggestive of meralgia paresthetica. It is due to compression neuropathy or neuroma of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. The root value of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is L2 and L3.

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3, and it supplies the skin of the anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh up to the knee.

It is prone to injury especially as it leaves the pelvis deep to the inguinal ligament just medial to the anterior superior iliac spine. The angulation of the nerve as it crosses the iliac crest makes it vulnerable to compression during hip extension which may increase angulation and tension on the nerve.

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

Syndrome 

Nerve involved

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Ulnar nerve behind medial epicondyle

Cheiralgia Paresthetica (Wartenburg syndrome)

Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Median nerve (at wrist)

Guyon's canal syndrome

Ulnar nerve(at wrist)

Thoracic outlet syndrome

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Tarsal tunnel syndrome

Posterior tibial nerve

Piriformis syndrome

Sciatic nerve
Meralgia paresthetica Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Mortons Metatarsalgia Interdigital plantar nerve 
Notalgia Paresthetica Superficial sensory neuropathy in the infrascapular area (Pruritus + Dysaesthesia)

questions.text: Which of the following structure is not crossed by the root of the mesentery?
questions.solution:
Right ureter(and not left ureter) is crossed by the root of the mesentery.

Structures crossed by the root of the mesentery include:

  • The third part of the duodenum
  • Abdominal aorta
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right ureter
  • Right psoas major

The root of the mesentery is the attachment of the mesentery of the small intestine to the posterior abdominal wall. It runs diagonally from the duodenojejunal flexure on the left side of the L2 vertebral body to the right sacroiliac joint.

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures of the femoral triangle from medial to lateral.
  1. Femoral nerve
  2. Sartorius
  3. Femoral vein
  4. Femoral artery
  5. Adductor longus
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of structures of the femoral triangle from medial to lateral is 5-3-4-1-2 i.e. adductor longus - femoral vein - femoral artery - femoral nerve - sartorius. 

The femoral triangle is an intermuscular space present in the anterior, proximal thigh. It is an inverted and depressed triangular space. The boundaries of the triangle include:

  • Base - inguinal ligament
  • Medial border - adductor longus
  • Lateral border - sartorius
  • Apex - confluence of the sartorius and adductor longus. 

Contents of the femoral triangle from medial to lateral are as follows- deep inguinal lymph nodes, femoral vein, femoral artery, and femoral nerve. 

The cadaveric image given below shows the contents of the femoral triangle.

The image given below shows the muscles forming the floor of the femoral triangle.

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: Which of the following types of secretion is seen in mammary glands?
questions.solution:
The type of glandular secretion seen in mammary glands is Apocrine.

Types of glands:

Apocrine Holocrine Eccrine (Merocrine)
Apical part of cell sheds off during discharge Whole-cell disintegrates during discharge The cell is intact and secretions are thrown out by exocytosis
Eg: Apocrine sweat glands in axilla and groin, mammary glands, the external auditory canal (ceruminous glands) and eyelids (glands of Moll)

Eg: Glands of Zeis and Meibomian gland 

Montgomery tubercle: Nipple and areola

Tyson's gland: External fold of the prepuce

Fordyce' spot: Vermillion border of lips and mucosa

Eg: Sweat glands on palms and soles

Found everywhere except clitoris, glans penis, labia minora, external auditory canal and lips

questions.text: The given image is a dissected specimen of the posterior surface of the knee. What is the nature of the gait associated with damage to the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the common peroneal nerve. It is also called the common fibular nerve. Damage to it would result in a high stepping gait.

The common peroneal nerve descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa, until the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris. The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis, which are the evertors of the foot, and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot, except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment, which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

Common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop (image below shows a foot drop in the right calf)
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion
  • A diminished sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved

Other options:

  • Cautious gait is seen in persons with spinal TB; they will walk carefully with short steps to avoid pain resulting from movement.
  • Wide-stepping gait is a broad-based unstable gait and is indicative of cerebellar dysfunction.
  • Waddling gait is seen in developmental dysplasia of the hip and in proximal muscle weakness.

Related Pearl: Sciatic nerve divisions and supply

 
Sciatic nerve divisions and its supply 
Tibial division
Motor: 
semitendinous, semimembranous, long head biceps femoris, gastrocnemius popliteus, plantaris, soleus, tibialis posterior, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, abductor hallucis, flexor digit­orum brevis, flexor hallucis brevis, addcutor hallucis, foot interossei, abductor digiti minimi.
 
Sensory: 
none
Peroneal division
Motor:
short head of biceps femoris, foot interossei, Tibialis anterior, Extensor Hallucis longus, Extensor digitorum longus and Peroneus tertius, Peroneus Longus, Peroneus Brevis.
 
Sensory:
articular branch to knee joint
sural nerve branch 
- closeby structure: saphenous vein, achilles tendon
- anastomoses: br. of peroneal nerve
- termination as: lateral dorsal cutaneous nerve

questions.text: In the given image, the structure marked as "C" develops from which of the following?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as C in the given image is the medulla oblongata, which develops from myelencephalon. It is a part of the rhombencephalon.

The rhombencephalon is subdivided into a cranial part—the metencephalon—and a caudal part—the myelencephalon.

  • The metencephalon forms the pons and cerebellum(marked as B and D respectively)
  • The myelencephalon forms the medulla oblongata.

Mesencephalon forms midbrain which is marked as "A" in the above image.

questions.text: A middle-aged man who presented with an abdominal mass has the following subcutaneous venous circulation with the direction of the flow as depicted by the arrows in the image. This can be seen in:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the upward flow of subcutaneous venous circulation can be seen in inferior vena cava obstruction.

The level of the umbilicus is a watershed area for venous and lymphatic circulation. The systemic veins anastomose with tributaries of portal veins at the umbilicus. Normally, venous blood and lymphatics flow upwards above the plane of the umbilicus and downwards below this plane. 

  • In inferior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal wall is completely upward.
  • In superior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal veins is completely downward.
  • In portal hypertension with dilated abdominal veins, the blood flow is away from the umbilicus, radiating like a star from the umbilicus (caput-medusae).

Causes of superior and inferior vena caval obstruction:

Causes of SVC obstruction Causes of IVC obstruction 

 

1. Mediastinal malignancy

2. Mediastinal fibrosis

3. Retrosternal thyroid

4. Aortic aneurysm

5. Radiation fibrosis

6. Iatrogenic
  1.  Thrombosis extension
  2.  Tumor invasion
  3.  Extrinsic compression (Eg: Pregnancy, abdominal mass)
  4. Coagulopathy
  5. Sepsis, dehydration, immobility
  6. Iatrogenic

Splenic vein thrombosis is one of the prehepatic causes of portal hypertension, in which the portal venous system is affected before it enters the liver.

questions.text: A 40-year old female underwent total thyroidectomy and on the third postoperative day, the patient complains of numbness in her fingers and perioral area. Which of the following vessels would have been injured during the surgery?

choices.text: Anterior branch of superior thyroid artery
Posterior branch of superior thyroid artery
Superior branch of inferior thyroid artery
Inferior branch of inferior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of postoperative hypoparathyroidism due to injury to the superior branch of the inferior thyroid artery.

The parathyroid glands are small yellowish-brown structures lying between the posterior border of the thyroid gland and its capsule.  There are

  • Two superior parathyroid glands 
  • Two inferior parathyroid glands

These are supplied by the superior branch of the inferior thyroid artery. They secrete parathormone which helps in the regulation of the serum calcium, by the release of calcium from bones.

questions.text: The structure marked as '?' in the image below connects which of the following two ventricles?

choices.text: Third ventricle with the lateral ventricles
Third ventricle with the fourth ventricle
Lateral ventricle with the fourth ventricle

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius which connects the third ventricle with the fourth ventricle.

The cerebral aqueduct is a small, approximately circular tube with a diameter of 1-2 mm. It runs along the midline of the dorsal quarter of the midbrain, surrounded by the periaqueductal (central) grey matter. At the rostral end, it starts just below the posterior commissure and connects to the caudal aspect of the third ventricle. At the caudal end, it continues into the fourth ventricle, located at the junction of the midbrain and pons. In children with von Recklinghausen's disease, primary aqueductal stenosis is a characteristic feature.

 

Other options:

Option A - The third ventricle is connected to the lateral ventricles via the interventricular foramina of Monro on either side.

questions.text: Identify the marked artery.
questions.solution:
The artery marked is the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. This artery branches out from the vertebral artery and it is the largest branch of the vertebral artery.

The following image shows the circle of Willis.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: While examining the hypoglossal nerve in a stroke patient, you observe the following finding. Which of the following muscles is likely to be paralyzed?
questions.solution:
The given image shows tongue deviation to the left, and the left genioglossus muscle is paralyzed in the above given clinical scenario.

Actions of genioglossus muscle:

  • When both the right and left genioglossi contract, they protrude the anterior part of the tongue out of the mouth in the midline. When only one muscle contracts, it protrudes and pushes the tongue to the opposite side.
  • It depresses the central part of the tongue.
  • It is supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. 

In conditions affecting the hypoglossal nerve, the genioglossus muscle on that side is paralyzed. In such cases, when the patient protrudes the tongue, it deviates towards the affected side due to the muscle contraction on the normal side.

The genioglossi are attached to the genial tubercle present on the mandible. This prevents the tongue from falling backwards and obstructing respiration. Hence this muscle is known as the safety muscle of the tongue.

questions.text: An orthopedic surgeon was a bit apprehensive in giving a medicolegal opinion to a male patient who had met with a road traffic accident. The following image shows the x-ray of his left ankle. He finally concluded the finding in x-ray to be a normal variant, as the patient and felt reassured by the fact that he had a similar finding on the other ankle as well. Which of the following terminology suits well to describe this normal variant?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bony projection behind the talus suggestive of os trigonum, and this is called a supernumerary bone.

Accessory bones, also known as supernumerary bones are not always present. They may arise due to ununited epiphysis developed from extra ossification centres. Clinically, they may be mistaken for fractures. However, these bones maybe bilateral and have smooth surfaces without any callus

Examples of accessory bones:

  • Os trigonum:  Uncommon accessory bone seen behind the talus. Also known as the lateral tubercle of the talus.
  • Os vesalianum: Uncommon accessory bone located proximal to the fifth metatarsal and found within the peroneus brevis tendon. Also known as tuberosity of the fifth metatarsal.

questions.text: In which of the following marked areas, the liver is not covered by visceral peritonium?
questions.solution:
The part of the liver marked with 'B' is the bare area of the liver, as this area marks the portion of the liver which is not covered by visceral peritoneum.

The bare area of the liver is a triangular area of the liver that is devoid of peritoneal covering. It is formed by the two layers of the coronary ligament. In this bare area, the liver is attached to the diaphragm by areolar tissue.

questions.text: A 35-year-old athlete presents with posterior shoulder pain and paresthesia over the right lateral arm. Following the investigations, after excluding all other causes, you diagnose it as quadrangular space syndrome due to hypertrophy of Teres major. This hypertrophied muscle forms which boundary of the quadrangular space?
questions.solution:
Teres Major forms the inferior boundary of the Quadrangular space.

Quadrangular space (Foramen of Velpeau) is a passageway for the nerves and vessels between the axilla anteriorly and the scapular region posteriorly.

Boundaries: Formed by 4 borders (Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral):

  • Superiorly by Capsule of the Shoulder joint, Teres Minor
  • Inferiorly by Teres Major
  • Medially by the Long head of Triceps and
  • Laterally by Surgical Neck of Humerus.

Contents: Axillary nerve and Posterior circumflex humeral artery and vein.

Quadrangular space syndrome: The condition is caused by hypertrophy or fibrosis of the quadrangular space muscles which impinge on the axillary nerve. The patient presents with weakness of the shoulder movements. Since many other conditions can mimic QSS, it is often a diagnosis of exclusion. Conservative treatment is often first trialled, including physical exercise modification, physical therapy, and therapeutic massage. If unrelieved by conservative measures, surgical decompression of the quadrilateral space may be indicated.

The image below shows spaces around the shoulder joint. (QS: Quadrangular space, TS: Superior triangular space, TI: Triangular interval).

An easy way to remember these spaces is to represent your 4 fingers as structures around the 3 spaces as shown below.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding superior orbital fissure?

choices.text: Lacrimal nerve and Frontal nerve pass above the common tendinous ring
Superior division of oculomotor nerve passes above the common tendinous ring while the inferior division  passes below it.
Abducens nerve and Nasociliary nerve pass within the common tendinous ring
Inferior ophthalmic vein passes below the common tendinous ring

questions.solution:
Both divisions of the oculomotor nerve pass within the common tendinous ring.

Superior orbital fissure is divided into three compartments by the common tendinous ring.

Compartments

Contents

Superolateral compartments

Lacrimal, frontal and trochlear nerve (LFT). Superior ophthalmic vein

Intermediate compartment

Superior and inferior division of oculomotor, Nasociliary nerve, Abducent nerve

Inferomedial compartment

Inferior ophthalmic vein

 

Related Pearl: Superior orbital fissure

Structures passing through the Superior orbital fissure

Above the common tendinous ring: LFT (Superolateral compartment)

  • Lacrimal nerve
  • Frontal nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • Superior opthalmic vein

Within the common tendinous ring: BAN (Intermediate compartment)

  • Both divisions of oculomotor nerve
  • Abducens nerve
  • Nasociliary nerve

Below the common tendinous ring (Inferomedial compartment)

  • Inferior ophthalmic vein

questions.text: The following structure (arrowed) is marked during an anatomy practical exam. Which of the following structure does not contain the same type of white matter fibre present in the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the fornix which contains the association fibres. The commissure of the fornix/Hippocampal commissure is made up of commissural fibres, not association fibres. 

The fornix is a part of the connecting pathways of the limbic system. It arises from the hippocampus which wraps around the thalamus and ends in the mammillary body. It connects the hippocampus with distal brain sites. 

The fornix has two types of fibres:

  • Association fibres: They connect the various cortical regions within the same hemisphere 
  • Commissural fibres: They connect the corresponding regions of two hemispheres. It is seen in the hippocampal commissure of the fornix. 

It is supplied by the anterior communicating artery arising from the anterior cerebral artery. The fibres present in the fornix are association fibres except for the hippocampal commissure of the fornix which has commissural fibres. 

Uncinate fasciculus and the Cingulum contains long association fibres. Arcuate fasciculus/U fibres have short association fibres. 

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is admitted to the hospital with a hearing defect. An MRI examination reveals that she has development defects in the auditory tube and middle ear cavity. Which of the following marked embryonal structures is most likely to be developed abnormally?
questions.solution:
In this girl, there is a developmental defect of the auditory tube and middle ear cavity. Therefore, the first pharyngeal pouch is most likely to be developed abnormally which is marked as "1" in the given image.

questions.text: Which of the following cells have haploid number of chromosomes?
questions.solution:
Secondary spermatocytes have haploid number of chromosomes.

During the process of spermatogenesis, each primary spermatocyte gives rise to 4 sperm cells (in contrast, each primary oocyte gives rise to only 1 ovum). The haploid cells formed during this process are secondary spermatocytes, spermatids, and spermatozoa.

questions.text:
The actions of the muscle attached to the area marked by the red arrow are:

1. Depression of mandible
2. Protrusion of mandible
3. Side to side movement of the jaw.
4. Elevation of mandible
5. Retraction of mandible
questions.solution:
The marked area is pterygoid fovea where the lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted. The action of this muscle is depression, protrusion, and side to side movement of the jaw.

In addition, lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted into the articular disc and capsule of TMJ.

The lateral pterygoid has the following actions:

  1. Opening of the jaw (depression): Lateral pterygoid has a specialized role in mandibular opening mediated by its horizontal fibres. When left and right lateral pterygoid muscles contract together, the mandibular condyle is pulled forwards and slightly downwards. This protrusive movement alone has little or no function except in assisting the opening the jaw (Gray's Anatomy 41st edition).
  2. Side-to-side movement: When the lateral pterygoid contracts unilaterally along with the adjacent medial pterygoid the jaw is pulled medially. This is used for grinding food between teeth of the same side. This action is mediated by the inferior head of lateral pterygoid.

Masseter muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of zygomatic bone and zygomatic arch.
  • Insertion - It inserted into the lateral surface of ramus of the mandible and coronoid process



Temporalis muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from the temporal fossa and deep surface of temporal fascia.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the coronoid process and to the anterior border of the ramus of the mandible up to the third molar tooth.

Lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. 
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule of the temporomandibular joint, and articular disc.

 Medial pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Deep head arises from medial surface of lateral pterygoid plate and pyramidal process of palatine bone. Superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and pyramidal process of palatine bone
  • Insertion- It is inserted into the medial surface of the ramus, near the angle of mandible

Note:

  • Among the four mastication muscles (temporalis, masseter, medial pterygoid, lateral pterygoid), the lateral pterygoid is the only muscle that helps in depression/opening of the jaw. 
  • The main jaw opener muscles are digastric and geniohyoid

questions.text: Clinical presentation with urine draining from the umbilicus is a feature of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause here should be a urachal fistula since urine is leaking from the umbilicus.

During embryonic development, the upper end of the urogenital sinus communicates with the allantois, which lies in the umbilical cord. The allantois normally regresses to form a fibrous cord called the urachus. In the adult, the urachus is seen as the median umbilical ligament.

Remnants of the urachus that may be seen after birth:

  • Urachal cyst: If a local area of allantois persists, the secretions inside result in a dilated cyst.
  • Urachal fistula: When the allantois persists the whole length, a fistula connects the umbilicus to the bladder.
  • Urachal sinus: When the lumen of the allantois persists only in the upper part, a sinus is formed that opens at the umbilicus. 
  • Bladder diverticulum: When the lumen of allantois persists only in the lower part, a blind-ending tract is seen upwards from the bladder.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the muscle marked by the red arrow?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the first lumbrical. It is supplied by the median nerve. The muscle arises from the radial side of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon of the index finger. The muscle is unipennate.
